questions.text: A patient presents with multiple skin lesions as shown. His mother and brother also have the same disease. What is not true about this disease ?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

The clinical presentation described here points towards Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF-1) and the characteristic skin tumors in NF-1 are cutaneous neurofibromas, not collagenomas.

Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF-1) is also known as Von Recklinghausen disease, which follows an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern. It’s common to see multiple family members affected, as indicated by the presence of the disease in both the patient's mother and brother.

Button hole sign: This sign refers to the ability to invaginate a neurofibroma by applying pressure with the tip of the index finger, causing it to push back into the subcutaneous tissue. Once the pressure is released, the neurofibroma reappears on the skin surface, as the lesion is soft and mobile.

The primary skin manifestations of Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1) include:

  • Cafe-au-lait macules: These are well-defined, light brown patches that are typically the earliest cutaneous manifestation of NF1. (Option A ruled out)
  • Axillary and inguinal freckling (Crowe's sign): Freckling in the axillae or groin is pathognomonic for NF1 and often appears during early childhood. (Option B ruled out)
  • Cutaneous neurofibromas: These are soft, lilac-pink tumours, sessile and dome shaped, and sometimes pedunculated. They are derived from peripheral nerves and their supporting structures, including neurilemmal cells.
  • Plexiform neurofibromas: These are diffuse, elongated fibromas along the course of a nerve, frequently involving the trigeminal or upper cervical nerves.They have a distinctive ‘bag of worms’ feeling on palpation
  • Lisch nodules: These are pigmented hamartomas of the iris, that appear as dome-shaped lesions on the iris, detectable by slit-lamp examination.

Explanation of other options:

Pseudoarthrosis of long bones is seen (Option C): Pseudoarthrosis, especially of the tibia, is a recognized skeletal complication of NF1.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents due to concerns about vision in his left eye. He has a history of multiple brown patches on his skin and freckling in the axillae. His mother has similar skin lesions. On ophthalmological examination, the following finding is seen. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • The clinical finding described in the question is Lisch nodules which are characteristic of Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF-1), also known as Von Recklinghausen's disease.
  • Lisch nodules are pigmented iris hamartomas. They appear as dome- shaped lesions found superficially around the iris on slit lamp examination. They are asymptomatic.
  • Other ocular manifestation of NF-1: Optic nerve glioma

Explanation of other options:

Albright’s syndrome (McCune-Albright syndrome) (Option A): Characterized by café-au-lait spots, fibrous dysplasia of bone, and endocrinopathies (e.g., precocious puberty), but does not include Lisch nodules

Tuberous sclerosis (Option C): Presents with ash-leaf macules, angiofibromas, shagreen patches, and retinal hamartomas, but not Lisch nodules

Piebaldism (Option D): A congenital condition with patches of depigmented skin and hair, typically due to mutations affecting melanocyte development, and unrelated to iris findings

questions.text: A 9-year-old child presents with the skin lesions shown in the images above. Which of the following conditions is not typically associated with this syndrome?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

The images show classic dermatologic signs of Tuberous Sclerosis Complex (TSC): Ash-leaf macules and Periungual fibromas (Koenen tumors). Optic pathway glioma is characteristic of Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1), not TSC.

  • Tuberous Sclerosis Complex (TSC) represents a genetic disorder of hamartoma formation in many organs, particularly the skin, brain, eye, kidney and heart. It follows an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance.
  • The characteristic features of the syndrome are skin lesions, intellectual impairment and epilepsy
  • Skin lesions of 4 types are pathognomonic
    • Angiofibromas: Firm, discrete, red brown, telangiectatic papules, 1-10mm in diameter, extending from naso-labial furrows to cheeks and chin, and occasionally in the ears, usually appear between 3 to 10 years of age. Formerly misnamed adenoma sebaceum. (Option D ruled out)
    • Periungual fibromas (Koenen tumours): appear at or after puberty as smooth, firm flesh coloured excrescences emerging from the nail folds.
    • Shagreen patches: Irregularly thickened, slightly elevated, soft, skin coloured plaque, usually in the lumbosacral region.
    • White ovoid or ash-leaf-shaped macules: 1-3cm in length, most easily detectable by examination under Wood’s light, frequently present on trunk or limbs
  • Other cutaneous manifestations include firm fibromatous plaques, especially on the forehead and scalp, soft pedunculated fibromas around the neck and axillae, and poliosis.
  • Other key associations include:
    • Heart: rhabdomyomas (especially in infants) (Option C ruled out)
    • Kidneys: angiomyolipomas, renal cysts (Option B ruled out)
    • Lungs: lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM), can cause recurrent spontaneous pneumothorax, chylothorax
    • Eyes: retinal phacomas
    • GIT: Hamartomatous colonic polyps

Endocrine: Pituitary-adrenal dysfunction, thyroid disorders, premature puberty

questions.text:
A 15 year old girl presents with reddish papules on the face. Which of the following findings may be noted on further examination and investigations.


1. Lisch nodule
2. Renal Cortical Cyst
3. Rhabdomyoma of heart and lung
4. Neurofibromas
5. Koenon tumor
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

The reddish papules seen on the face in the patient are consistent with facial angiofibromas (also known as adenoma sebaceum), which are a characteristic feature of Tuberous Sclerosis Complex (TSC).

Tuberous Sclerosis Complex (TSC) represents a genetic disorder of hamartoma formation in many organs, particularly the skin, brain, eye, kidney and heart. It follows an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance.

  • The characteristic features of the syndrome are skin lesions, intellectual impairment and epilepsy
  • Skin lesions of 4 types are pathognomonic
    • Angiofibromas: Firm, discrete, red brown, telangiectatic papules, 1-10mm in diameter, extending from naso-labial furrows to cheeks and chin, and occasionally in the ears, usually appear between 3 to 10 years of age. Formerly misnamed adenoma sebaceum. (Option D ruled out)
    • Periungual fibromas (Koenen tumours): appear at or after puberty as smooth, firm flesh coloured excrescences emerging from the nail folds.
    • Shagreen patches: Irregularly thickened, slightly elevated, soft, skin coloured plaque, usually in the lumbosacral region.
    • White ovoid or ash-leaf-shaped macules: 1-3cm in length, most easily detectable by examination under Wood’s light, frequently present on trunk or limbs

Periungual fibromas

Shagreen patches

Ash leaf macules

  • Other cutaneous manifestations include firm fibromatous plaques, especially on the forehead and scalp, soft pedunculated fibromas around the neck and axillae, and poliosis.
  • Other key associations include:
    • Heart: rhabdomyomas (especially in infants) (Option C ruled out)
    • Kidneys: angiomyolipomas, renal cysts (Option B ruled out)
    • Lungs: lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM), can cause recurrent spontaneous pneumothorax, chylothorax
    • Eyes: retinal phacomas
    • GIT: Hamartomatous colonic polyps
    • Endocrine: Pituitary- adrenal dysfunction, thyroid disorders, premature puberty

Explanation of other options:

Lisch nodules (1): These are pigmented iris hamartomas seen in Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1), not TSC.

Neurofibromas (4): Also characteristic of NF1, not TSC.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is useful in a patient with extensive adenoma sebaceum on the face:
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

Facial angiofibromas are benign skin hamartomas commonly seen in patients with Tuberous Sclerosis Complex. While they are non-cancerous, they can be disfiguring and psychologically distressing, especially in adolescents.

Mechanism of Treatment:

  • Sirolimus (Rapamycin) is an mTOR inhibitor, targeting the molecular pathway that drives hamartoma growth in TSC.
  • Topical formulations of sirolimus or its analog, everolimus, have shown significant improvement in lesion size and color in clinical studies, with minimal adverse effects.

Explanation of other options:

Tretinoin (Option A):  primarily used for acne and keratinization disorders; not effective for angiofibromas

Topical steroids (Option C):  anti-inflammatory, but not helpful for hamartomatous growths

Tacrolimus (Option D):  an immunomodulator used in atopic dermatitis; no role in angiofibroma regression

questions.text: A 2 year old girl presented with lesions as shown in the image. Her mother had history of in-utero child death and hypopigmented atrophic linear lesions. The diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

Incontinentia Pigmenti (IP) is a rare X-linked dominant neurocutaneous syndrome caused by mutations in the NEMO (IKBKG) gene. It is lethal in most males and hence typically seen in females.

Key Diagnostic Features:

  • Blaschkoid distribution of skin lesions
  • Lesions evolve through 4 distinct stages (VVHH):
    • Vesicular (at birth or in utero)
    • Verrucous (linear, hyperkeratotic papules)
    • Hyperpigmentation (swirled brown/grey pigmentation)
    • Hypopigmentation (atrophic, linear lesions—seen in this case)

Vesiculobullous stage

Verrucous stage

Pigmentary stage

Hyperpigmented stage with hair loss

Associated Findings:

  • CNS: Seizures, developmental delay, microcephaly
  • Eyes: Retinal vascular abnormalities, strabismus, optic atrophy
  • Teeth: Delayed dentition, peg-shaped teeth
  • Skeletal: Limb anomalies

Family History Clue:

Maternal hypopigmented streaks + in-utero fetal death of male siblings supports X-linked dominant inheritance with male lethality.

Explanation of other options:

Neurofibromatosis  (Option A): Café-au-lait spots, axillary freckling, neurofibromas—not linear hypopigmented lesions.

Xeroderma pigmentosum (Option B): Severe UV sensitivity and pigmentation issues in sun-exposed areas, not Blaschkoid pattern.

Tuberous sclerosis (Option C): Hypomelanotic macules ("ash leaf spots"), shagreen patches, angiofibromas—but not Blaschkoid or staged lesions.

questions.text: A 7 years old child presents with freckles, telangiectatic spots, photosensitivity, microcephaly. Sibling also suffers from similar symptoms. The diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

Xeroderma pigmentosum (XP) is a rare autosomal recessive genodermatosis caused by mutations in genes involved in nucleotide excision repair (NER). This DNA repair pathway is responsible for removing UV-induced DNA damage, particularly pyrimidine dimers.

Clinical Features of XP:

  • Exaggerated sunburn from early infancy
  • Freckling, hypo-/hyperpigmentation, and telangiectasias in sun-exposed areas
  • Increased incidence of UVR-induced skin and mucous membrane cancers at sun exposed sites: non- melanoma skin cancers (NMSC) and melanoma skin cancer
  • Increased incidence of other malignancies- smoking induced lung cancer, cancers of the brain,
  • Neurodegeneration
  • Ocular involvement: photophobia, keratitis, premature pingueculae, pterygia, ocular surface cancers

Incorrect options explained:

Cockayne syndrome (Option B): Also features photosensitivity and neurodegeneration, but typically includes cachectic dwarfism, hearing loss, retinal degeneration, and no increased cancer risk.

Bloom's syndrome (Option C): Features include growth deficiency, photosensitivity, and increased cancer risk, but it is more associated with chromosomal instability and butterfly-shaped rash on the face, not freckling with severe photosensitivity.

Neurofibromatosis type II (Option D): Characterized by bilateral vestibular schwannomas, hearing loss, and café-au-lait spots, not photosensitivity or DNA repair defects.
